pull.title: [0.12.2] backport: getblockchaininfo: make bip9_softforks an object, not an array.
pull.body: This breaks the interface but it was tagged with 'Needs backport' and I think it is useful. Other opinions?

milestone.title: 0.12.branch
milestone.description: There won't be a release after the 0.12.1, but bugfixes can still go to the 0.12 branch

events.body: Nah I think it makes sense to backport this in preparation for 0.13. Maybe mention in the release notes? Not sure how many people rely on this programmatically.

events.message:
getblockchaininfo: make bip9_softforks an object, not an array.

Github-Pull: #7863
Rebased-From: 85c807c9ead3215021503348e75851900dfa08db d12760b16ac30734b5e3b047df8aaf6564e927db

events.body: Updated the release notes just to be safe.

Nothing specific, just lack of review and testing as usual with backports.
I'll take a look at it.

Eh, breaking API compatibility in a bugfix release? I don't see any real benefit to this. If people want the new API, they can just use 0.13. We've never broken API compatibility before in even a major release... now isn't the time to do it in a bugfix release. :/

The idea would be to have the same API on 0.12 and 0.13, which makes e.g. testing easier (also for e.g. segwit).
But I don't care deeply whether this makes it into 0.12...

You do have a point that this would be an API-breaking change in a minor releaese.

events.message: [doc] Update release notes for change in getblockchaininfo

events.body: Closing this, apparently it is controversial

comments.body:
Nit: usually we call this category "RPC low-level API changes"
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v0.12.0/doc/release-notes.md#rpc-low-level-api-changes
